title: feat: Portkey integration with Llama_index
body:
# Description

This pull request introduces the Portkey integration to the Llama_index repository, enhancing its production capabilities. Portkey offers a comprehensive set of tools and features to optimize the performance and reliability of AI applications.

### Key Features of Portkey's Integration with Llamaindex:
1. **AI Gateway**:
    - **Automated Fallbacks & Retries**: Ensure your application remains functional even if a primary service fails.
    - **Load Balancing**: Efficiently distribute incoming requests among multiple models.
    - **Semantic Caching**: Reduce costs and latency by intelligently caching results.
2. **Observability**:
    - **Logging**: Keep track of all requests for monitoring and debugging.
    - **Requests Tracing**: Understand the journey of each request for optimization.
    - **Custom Tags**: Segment and categorize requests for better insights.

### Changes Made:
Incorporated a new LLM (Large Language Model) within the LLMs folder, which inherits from the existing CustomLLM class. This new LLM is responsible for integrating and utilizing Portkey's enhanced production capabilities while maintaining consistency with the repository's coding standards.

### Dependencies:
This integration introduces one external library called "Rubeus," which is added to the list of dependencies. Rubeus is an integral part of Portkey and contributes to its internal functioning.

Fixes # (issue)

## Type of Change

title: Postgres hybrid search (gitpeppy changes)
body:
# Description

[Original PR](https://github.com/gitpeppy/llama_index/tree/hybrid_postgres_poc) from @gitpeppy for hybrid search in postgres vector db integration.

Additional changes
* Fix bugs in test code
  * previously some tests were always running in async instead of async/sync versions
  * previously example vector embeddings were all co-linear, so had the same cosine distance, and tests were only passing because initial insertion ordering
* Fix keyword search SQL to properly use `ts_query` in the where clause
* update notebook & changelog.

The KG index was having a few weird issues

title: update vector dim for PGVectorStore
body:
# Description

This update allows the `embed_dim` for `PGVectorStore` to be configurable

```python
vector_store = PGVectorStore.from_params(..., embed_dim=1536)
...
vector_store = PGVectorStore(..., embed_dim=1536)
```

If a user uses an embedding model larger than the previous hardcoded dim of 1536, there will be an error.

Fixes https://github.com/jerryjliu/llama_index/issues/7490

title: Support pydantic v2
body:
# Description

This provides soft support for Pydantic v2 by leaning on the compatibility layer for pydantic v1 added in pydantic v2.

The change amounts to trying to import v1 from v2 and in the case that it fails (meaning v2 isn't currently installed), it defaults to the v1 import pattern. The actual functionality of the imported classes / functions remains the same regardless of whether its coming from v1 or v2 so no major refactor or logic changes w/ testing is required. 

NOTE: This should be a short term "bandaid" fix and replaced whenever the bandwidth to do so becomes available as its a really bad pattern to have in a code base. Its important to get this in though as major libraries are moving to full v2-only implementations and blocking updating them is worse than the quality of this code :P

Fixes #7393

## Type of Change

title: enhancement: add max_tokens to xinference
body: # Description This is a non-breaking update on the Xinference extension targeting [this issue](https://github.com/xorbitsai/inference/issues/378). Currently, the `Xinference` object does not support changing the output length. This results in answers being cropped off before the model generates the stop token naturally, leading to unfinished answers. This PR adds the `max_token` argument to `Xinference`, which depends on the context window of the model. The context window argument is also updated so that information is fetched from the Xinference endpoint directly instead of locally stored in the codebase, removing the need for frequent future updates as Xinference incorporates more language models. This is a non-breaking fix. The `max_token` argument is optional, so all old code operates normally. Relevant use case examples would be updated in the demo notebook and documents. ## Type of Change Please delete options that are not relevant. - [X] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [X] This change requires a documentation update # How Has This Been Tested? - [x] Added new unit/integration tests - [x] Updated test notebook (that tests end-to-end) - [x] Updated relevant documentation - [x] I stared at the code and made sure it makes sense

title: Fixed OpenAiAgent force function call loop
body:
# Description

When a function call was forced on the OpenAiAgent, a loop occurred where each response of the LLM called the function again and therefore never send a final response. To fix this, the custom value gets only applied at the first request. After that the function parameter in the OpenAi Api changes back to `auto`. For more information about this parameter, look at the [OpenAi API documentation](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/chat/create#chat/create-functions).

Fixes #7359

title: Function schema description
body:
# Description

Previously, if you did this:

```python
from llama_index.tools.function_tool import FunctionTool
from pydantic import Field

def multiply(a: int, b: int = Field(..., description="You'd better B-lieve it!")) -> int:
    """Multiple two integers and returns the result integer"""
    return a * b
multiply_tool = FunctionTool.from_defaults(fn=multiply)
multiply_tool.metadata.to_openai_function()
```

You'd get hit by:

>> TypeError: Object of type 'FieldInfo' is not JSON serializable

Now, you get the `Field` description (and defaults) in the schema instead:

```json
{'name': 'multiply',
 'description': 'multiply(a: int, b: int = FieldInfo(default=Ellipsis, description="You\'d better B-lieve it!", extra={})) -> int\nMultiple two integers and returns the result integer',
 'parameters': {'title': 'multiply',
  'type': 'object',
  'properties': {'a': {'title': 'A', 'type': 'integer'},
   'b': {'title': 'B',
    'description': "You'd better B-lieve it!",
    'type': 'integer'}},
  'required': ['a', 'b']}}
```
## Type of Change
